org.jcatapult.domain.commerce
Class Money

java.lang.Object
  org.jcatapult.domain.commerce.Money
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Comparable<Money>
public class Money
extends Object
implements Serializable, Comparable<Money>

This class represents an internationalized monetary value.

See Also:

                            Currency currency)

currency - The currency.

The Money.

longValue

public long longValue()
Returns the amount of this Money as a long. This is the result of truncating any decimal part of the amount and returning it.

Returns:
The long value of the money.

doubleValue

public double doubleValue()
Returns this Money as a double. This conversion is not precise because it is the conversion from a BigDecimal to a double, which is lossy. This method should be avoided at all costs.

Returns:
The double value of the Money.

toBigDecimal

public BigDecimal toBigDecimal()
Returns the amount of this Money as a BigDecimal. The is the only precise way to get access to the amount of this Money.

Returns:
The amount of the Money.

toNumericString

public String toNumericString()
Returns:
A String representation of the money that has been rounded to the currencies fractional digits.

toString

public String toString()
Overrides:
toString in class Object
Returns:
A String of the money with the currency code for the current locale.

toString

public String toString(Locale locale)
Parameters:
locale - The locale to use for displaying the currency code.
Returns:
A String of the money with the currency code for the givan locale.

equalsRounded

public boolean equalsRounded(Money money)
This method compares the rounded values, which nearly always be equivalent depending on how that value was acquired. For example, 1.00/3 == 0.33. This is computed by converting the two Monies to rounded Strings and comparing the Strings.

Parameters:
money - The Money to compare.
Returns:
True if they are rounded and then equal, false if not.

equalsExact

public boolean equalsExact(Money money)
This method compares the exact values, which often will not be equivalent depending on how that value was acquired. For example, 1.00/3 != 0.33.

Parameters:
money - The Money to compare.
Returns:
True if they are exactly equal, false if not.

equals

public boolean equals(Object obj)
This throws an exception currently because of rounding issues.

Overrides:
equals in class Object
Parameters:
obj - Not used.
Returns:
Nothing.

isZero

public boolean isZero()
Returns:
True IFF the amount of this Money, when rounded to the number of fractional digits of the currency of the Money, is exactly equal to 0. For example, a Money value of 0.003 USD (three tenths of a percentage of a penny in U.S. dollars) will return true because this is less than zero and when rounded up will still be zero.

isZeroExact

public boolean isZeroExact()
Returns:
True IFF the amount of this Money has a value that is exactly equal to 0. For example, a Money value of 0.003 USD (three tenths of a percentage of a penny in U.S. dollars) will return false because this not exactly zero.

compareTo

public int compareTo(Money o)
Compares the given Money to this Money. If the currencies are not the same, this throws an exception.

Specified by:
compareTo in interface Comparable<Money>
Parameters:
o - The Money to compare with this Money.
Returns:
Positive number if this Money is more, negative it if is less, zero if they are equal.
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - If the currencies of this Money and the given Money aren't the same.
